summary: As previously discussed in topic 2.4, cell membranes don't let most things go through them. This has benefits to the cell, but also several downsides, the largest being that larger, useful, molecules (like glucose) cannot enter the cell. Topic 2.5 is about how the cell circumvents these problems.

vocab.definition: Occurs when there is a difference in concentration of a substance between two regions, and the substance will move from areas of high concentration to low until equilibrium is reached
The state where opposing biological processes occur at equal rates, resulting in no net change in the system, even though individual components are constantly changing and moving
The net movement of particles from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration (following the concentration gradient), driven by the random motion of molecules
The movement of molecules across a membrane from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration, without the cell expending its own energy
The passive movement of small, uncharged molecules from an area of high to low concentration directly through a cell's membrane, without the use of energy or transport proteins
A type of passive transport in which molecules move across a cell membrane through transport proteins (channels or carriers) down their concentration gradient, without additional energy
The cellular process of moving molecules across a cell membrane against their concentration gradient, requiring cellular energy, typically in the form of ATP, to drive the process
An active transport process where a cell uses its plasma membrane to engulf and internalize particles, such as large molecules, by forming membrane-bound vesicles
The process of phagocytes engulfing or ingesting cells to destroy them, a form of active transport
An active transport process where a cell uses its plasma membrane to engulf and internalize particles liquids and small molecules, by forming membrane-bound vesicles
A cellular process where specific molecules bind to cell-surface receptors, triggering the cell to engulf the receptor-ligand complex into a membrane-bound vesicle for internal transport
The biological process where membrane-bound vesicles inside a cell fuse with the cell's outer membrane, releasing their contents to the exterior
